faqs.question: What grades does GrowWise serve for summer camp?
faqs.answer: GrowWise summer camps in Dublin, CA serve Grades 3–12. Programs are grouped by age and readiness: Grades 3–6 (Robotics, Young Authors, Scratch Coding), Grades 4–8 (Math Olympiad Prep), Grades 7–12 (AI Entrepreneur Studio), and High School (Advanced Math: Algebra + Precalculus).

faqs.question: Are GrowWise summer camps in-person or online?
faqs.answer: We offer in-person and online options depending on the program. Robotics and Young Authors are full-day, in-person only in Dublin, CA. Scratch Coding, Math Olympiad Prep, AI Entrepreneur Studio, and Advanced Math may be available in-person or online by session.

faqs.question: Are the programs full-day or half-day?
faqs.answer: Full-day, in-person: Robotics (Grades 3–6) and Young Authors (Grades 3–6). Other programs vary by session length—check the schedule on the program page.

faqs.question: Where are GrowWise summer camps located?
faqs.answer: Our in-person camps are held at 4564 Dublin Blvd, Dublin, CA. Select programs also offer online sessions.

faqs.question: How do you group students by level?
faqs.answer: We group students by grade and readiness. For math and advanced programs, a brief placement check may be used so students feel challenged and supported.

faqs.question: What should my child bring to camp?
faqs.answer: Most campers should bring a water bottle, snack/lunch (if applicable), and a notebook/pencil. For tech programs (AI or coding), a laptop/device + charger may be required—see program details.

faqs.question: Do you offer sibling or multi-week discounts?
faqs.answer: Yes—sibling and multi-week discounts may be available on select programs. Discount details appear during registration.

faqs.question: What is your refund/cancellation policy?
faqs.answer: Refund and transfer options depend on the session. Please refer to the registration page for deadlines, deposits (if any), and transfer rules.

faqs.question: How do I register for GrowWise summer camp?
faqs.answer: Choose a program and session on thegrowwise.com, then complete checkout. If you have questions, contact GrowWise for support before enrolling.

faqs.question: What is AI Entrepreneur Studio?
faqs.answer: AI Entrepreneur Studio is a project-based AI summer program for Grades 7–12 where students build, test, and pitch real-world ideas using modern AI tools and entrepreneurship frameworks.

faqs.question: Do students need coding experience for AI camp?
faqs.answer: No. The program supports beginners through advanced. Beginners can use no-code tools and focus on product thinking, while advanced students can build more technical projects.

faqs.question: What will students create in AI Entrepreneur Studio?
faqs.answer: Students complete a portfolio-ready project, such as an AI-powered app/tool/chatbot/workflow, plus a validated business concept and a pitch deck + demo for a final presentation.

faqs.question: Does AI camp teach responsible AI use?
faqs.answer: Yes. Students learn safe use, accuracy checking, bias awareness, and ethical guidelines so they can use AI responsibly and effectively.

faqs.question: What skills will my teen gain in AI camp?
faqs.answer: Students build AI literacy, problem-solving, product design, entrepreneurship (validation + pitching), communication, and teamwork.

faqs.question: Do students need a laptop for AI camp?
faqs.answer: Typically yes. A laptop/Chromebook + charger is recommended for building and presenting AI projects (see program page for requirements).

faqs.question: What is the Robotics summer camp?
faqs.answer: Robotics is a full-day, in-person STEM camp for Grades 3–6 focused on hands-on builds, engineering challenges, and teamwork.

faqs.question: Is Robotics camp beginner-friendly?
faqs.answer: Yes—no prior robotics experience is needed. Students learn step-by-step and progress through fun challenges.

faqs.question: What will kids do in Robotics camp?
faqs.answer: Campers work on building and testing projects that develop engineering thinking, creativity, and problem-solving, including motion/design challenges and team builds.

faqs.question: What is Young Authors Camp (Book Publishing)?
faqs.answer: Young Authors is a full-day, in-person writing and book publishing camp for Grades 3–6 where students plan, draft, revise, and produce a final "published-style" writing project.

faqs.question: Is this writing camp good for reluctant writers?
faqs.answer: Yes. We use a storytelling-first approach with supportive coaching to build confidence and help students find their voice.

faqs.question: What will my child produce by the end of camp?
faqs.answer: Most campers leave with a completed writing project and a portfolio-style final piece they can share with family.

faqs.question: Who is Math Olympiad Prep for?
faqs.answer: Math Olympiad Prep is for Grades 4–8, ideal for students who enjoy challenges and want to improve contest-style problem solving.

faqs.question: What does Math Olympiad Prep cover?
faqs.answer: It focuses on math reasoning, strategy, and problem-solving commonly seen in Olympiad/competition math (logic, number sense, algebraic thinking, geometry, and more).

faqs.question: Is it only for students already doing competitions?
faqs.answer: No. Beginners are welcome. We teach strategies and thinking tools so students can grow quickly.

faqs.question: Who is Scratch Coding best for?
faqs.answer: Scratch is a great fit for beginner coders, commonly Grades 3–6, and supports older beginners too.

faqs.question: What will students build in Scratch?
faqs.answer: Students create games, animations, and interactive stories while learning foundational coding concepts like loops, conditionals, variables, and debugging.

faqs.question: Do students need a device for Scratch?
faqs.answer: If required, bring a laptop/Chromebook + charger (confirm device requirements on the program page).

faqs.question: Who should enroll in Advanced Math?
faqs.answer: Advanced Math is for high school students who want to strengthen Algebra and Precalculus foundations, accelerate learning, and build confidence for higher-level math.

faqs.question: Is Advanced Math only for "advanced" students?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Motivated students at different levels can succeed. Placement may be used to match the right group.

faqs.question: What topics are covered?
faqs.answer: Topics include key Algebra and Precalculus skills such as functions, equations, graphs, and foundational trigonometry concepts, depending on level.
